review:
If you liked Lemlings as a kid and would like to see how that would be with sheep and power ups to apply to said sheep then you will most likely enjoy this game.

There are a lot of levels to this game and just like the classic games of this genre your sheep will keep on moving at all times and you need to place things or power them up to make them get past obstacles or not walking into their own deaths. There was some jank with the videos though that made my computer crash, but y'know. Oldish game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198827738835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1667536578}
review:
The top review says everything that needs to be said:

"
Despite appearances Flockers does not play much like Lemmings.

Lemmings is primarily a puzzle game, not an action game. Flockers is primarily an action game, not a puzzle game. The difference is whether you put the emphasis on difficult reasoning or reacting quickly.

Flockers plays more like some sort of strange platformer than a Lemmings clone. Unlike Lemmings, there is no way to assign tasks while the game is paused or even slowed down.

Assigning tasks is made more unpleasant by the design of flocker tasks. In Lemmings assigning a single lemming a task typically affected the behavior of the entire stream of lemmings, or terrain, such as blocking their path and turning them around, or building a staircase until an obstacle was struck. In Flockers you usually need to give the same task to each flocker at the right time. Too late is fatal. Too early may also be fatal, depending on the task and environment. The only concession the controls make for these demands is to allow you to use a larger or smaller 'brush' to assign tasks, and due to the timing constraints a large brush is not very usable.

To make matters worse, there is no way to predict what the level elements will do. This reduces solving the level to trial and error, rather than planning.

The constant trial and error gameplay is grueling since you will need to start the entire level over if you mess up badly enough.

If you want to see what it would be like to play Super Mario Bros. with awkward controls, a stream of Marios, and random cheap deaths, then play this. If you want to play something like Lemmings, you need to look elsewhere.

Some are making comparisons to Worms as well. There certainly is no similarity between Worms and Flockers gameplay. Both Lemmings and Worms had destructable environments. Flockers does not. While Worms was violent, and Lemmings had a task that made all the lemmings blow themselves up (used to restart the level), the violence was cartoony. Flockers is gory. So Flockers is not very comparable to Worms either."

POSTED: 22 JULY, 2015 By Coaldust

Es un juego como el pingus del Linux, tu objetivo es llevar ovejas del punto A al punto B (De extraccion). El juego se puede poner en pausa y acelerar.
Empezas con tipos de ovejas (desde 1 o mas puntos de inicio) y vas agarrando cajas en el juego que te habilitan formaciones en cubo, otros tipos de ovejas y explosion de oveja.
Las ovejas en Cubo simple, doble o escalerita sirven para trabar ovejas o para hacerlas superar obstaculos, tenes tambien Ademas de la oveja comun, las saltarinas (que saltan obstaculos hacia adelante) y trepadoras en 90Âº que van hacia arriba cuando tocan una pared.
Tambien segun la cantidad de ovejas que hay, pueden con el peso mover cosas hacia abajo, lo otro que tambien hay es la mecanica de que si caen muy lejos o saltan muy lejos mueren, Tiene 60 niveles el juego + 1 de bonificacion. 

Tambien estan estas mecanicas:
Oveja que explota para romper cajas en los costados o el piso y asi permitir el avance de las ovejas, tambien catapulta a otras ovejas hacia donde estan mirando y les permite alcanzar otros lugares
Ovejas dormidas (se unen luego de pasar cerca de ellas al juego) una explosion cercana puede despertar ovejas dormidas ej. que venga del piso de abajo
Las ovejas pueden morir por cosas que caen que estan suspendidas de cadenas de arriba ya sean pinchos, sierras, cajas, etc.
Las minas pueden hacer volar tambien a las ovejas tambien hacen explotar cosas ej cajas y asi avanzas
Hay teletransportes de Punto A al B.
Hay como imanes que atraen ovejas hacia el techo o piso 
Las ovejas tocan botones que activan cosas, como sierras, saltos de fe estilo portal que catapultan la oveja hacia adelante y arriba y tambien y ascensores por nombrar algunos
Mecanica de fisicas interesantes como ovejas empujando un cilindro que luego cae por una pendiente y empuja varias estelas de piedra que caen en efecto domino y les deja pasar a las ovejas
En algunos niveles debes tener buen timing porque las ovejas se desplazan como en unos carros que se mueven y debes calcular bien como caer adentro y tocar otros botones
Siempre hay limite de tiempo de 10 miuntos para resolverlo
Podes Explotar barriles tambien para progapar explosion para romper cajas y madera
Se pueden usar objetos para presionar botones ej. un cilindro que cae luego de una explosion de una plataforma de madera y cae sobre el boton 

Estamos ante una maravilla estetica, de jugabilidad y visual, posee cromos, logros, marcador, editor de niveles y WORKSHOP, que en un tipo de juego como este, es LITERALMENTE lo que la gente reclama a gritos.

Es una propuesta un poco por afuera del team17 clasico, muy jugada, me gusta, bien hecha, buenos niveles, jugabilidad, duracion, realmente lo disfrute muchisimo, espero algun dia salga el 2!

review:
I played Lemmings as a child, and when I saw this game, I hoped it would be the perfect Lemmings remake.  It is not.  The beginning was promising.  The abilities are slightly different, but very familiar.  There are some nice quality of life features like a mass select for granting abilities to large groups, and prepositioning abilities so that you don't need to time your clicks carefully.  

But in actual gameplay the game falls far short.  In a classic Lemmings level you could pause the game upon level entry, and mentally solve it in its entirety before unpausing.  These levels are filled with switches with no clear indication of effect, moving deathtraps that cannot be blocked or avoided and must be navigated through careful timing (or luck), and busy level design that makes it extremely difficult to plan a level without first exploring it.  It's almost like the levels were designed for a typical puzzle platformer, and then retrofitted for Lemmings gameplay.

And perhaps the greatest sin of all:  Flockers has abandoned the classic Lemmings Nuke button for the more pedestrian 'restart' option.  What's even the point of playing a Lemmings-like game if you can't explode all of your minions the first time they walk off the wrong cliff?

The sheep are equipped with a variety of skills that they have developed over the course of their extensive service to worms, but they are not limited to just these. They can also be aided with utilities like climbing blocks. Frankly, the abilities and utilities are too few to create diversity, but the environment makes creative use of them, patching up the possibility of repetition. 

Flockers will challenge you with 66 (!) levels, many of which players may find too demanding. The traps are countless, and some puzzles will keep you awake at night in search of the solution. The difficulty is especially visible when you aim to max out the game; you might start struggling at the very beginning already. As a result, I'd love to see some sort of saving feature that allows you to correct mistakes or figure out what contraptions do without tearing your hair out. The pause is much-needed while in such trouble, but unfortunately it's far from perfect. You can't place blocks or assign abilities while it's active. Sometimes you have to pick a certain sheep among an accumulated herd, and if you happen to pick the wrong one, the whole run may go to waste.

It is also worth mentioning that the game allows players to play user-created levels, which extends the fun even further. It also pays an oddly large amount of attention to Twitch streaming.

I'm currently midway through the game, and I enjoy the content despite the difficulty and the developers' unwillingness to ease it up. The audio definitely brings it out better. To stay sane, I'd recommend breaking up the play into 1-2 level sessions. This product is definitely worth a recommendation for intermediate-difficult puzzle fans and wormers.

review:
This is basically lemmings...with sheep, but unfortunately it's not nearly as good. The graphics are muddy and ugly. Well, it's understandable, cause you're in a butcher factory or whatever, but I mean they're really detracting from the actual gameplay. The camera is sluggish. The game runs poorly on a modern rig and the overall gameplay is just not satisfying enough to carry it forward.

Your task, just as in lemmings, is to guide as many sheep to the exit, while sacrificing some on the way. For that you have various tools. Sorry, did I say various tools? Nah. Actually there are only 3 (jumping sheep, flying sheep and exploding sheep). The rest of the kit consists of "blocks", i.e. your sheep can be used as stepping stones (1, 2 or 3) like a staircase or as a soft block (2 sheep high), which means only flying sheep can cross over that. You can also release your sheep from stair or blocking duty. That is it. That is the game. At least that's what it's been for the first 10 or so levels. You get access to all the tools from the start.

To actually use these blocks you have to gather them in the level. The levels consist of different traps and teleporters, walls and gaps. Honestly, it's again, boring. There's nothing to really differentiate the levels from each other. They look and feel the same. Maybe this gets better later on, but if your game doesn't progress anywhere after 1 hour it's not worth my time anymore. There are also boss levels...the first one is you being chased by a giant "something" on wheels. Your sheep will die...horribly...and bloodily. And I guess this is the main selling point of the game. Since it is enough to get even a single sheep through to beat the level there's not much strategy involved, unless you want to go score attack...which with the amount of levels in there (a ton) sounds like work and not fun.

The controls are also kinda wonky, especially since you can't use the pause mode to actually plan stuff. In Lemmings you could assign individual lemmings to important roles. Here it's more like "paste that shit over every sheep to make them fly". Personally, I find this game to be dull and dreary. Maybe get it at a steep discount. 18 bucks is way too much for the level of polish you get here, though it does offer a decent amount of levels. Too bad the levels aren't interesting.

I'm about 3 levels into this game and, having bought it on sale, I had to wonder what all the complaining about the controls is all about.  Well, I did try the demo, and yes, the controls there are a hot mess.  It continually lost my customizations and there were several other really bad bugs during the demo.  By all rights, I shouldn't have bothered with the game.

But, I did.  And the full game has none of these issues so far.  Sure, it's not as tight as Lemmings was back in the day.  If it's possible to finish a level in Flockers without losing a sheep, then I haven't seen it so far.  It could drive a perfectionist nuts, I can see that.  That said, this is a more than playable and fun game which for the current price of $2 is a no-brainer. 

I'll update this review as I get a little further, but I just wanted to relate that because of the other reviews.  At the very least, I'm not going to return the game.

review: I loved Lemmings, and I wanted to love this. I thought it would be fun and hilarious, but it turned out to be quite frustrating. The learning curve is quite steep due to how easily the sheep die. Traps are everywhere, and you need to have sheep jump over buttons in order to prevent the release of the traps. These buttons are also used to progress, so you need to find a way to manage your sheep getting to the next area before allowing them to progress so that the sheep in front of the group doesn't release a trap killing all the sheep behind it. You also have to hope that the next area doesn't have more traps, otherwise you will need to find a way to let one sheep sacrifice itself first. You have very limited number of 'resources', and if you make one mistake, you've practically failed. There is not too much freedom of choice as to how to solve the very linear puzzles. It's unfortunate that there is also just so much going on at the same time that it becomes almost impossible to save all your sheep on any given level. It's a game of 'how many sheep can I prevent being killed by the traps in their path?', not 'how can I use my resources to overcome a challenging puzzle?'. In Lemmings, you could pause the game to assign commands to the Lemmings. In this game, you cannot. Timing is more important than the puzzles themselves, which is dissapointing. Also, you generally have to assign commands to every single sheep in the line, or else they will die (eg. failing to assign the jump command to every passing sheep will cause them all to fall and die.). You had better hope too that you have enough time to manage the sheep that have jumped already, and on their way to their doom and the sheep that you haven't assigned yet! Completing the early 'puzzles' didn't give me any feelings of joy or achievement, so I stopped playing this game quite early. I may come back again to it... but I'll give it a rest for now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998031554', 'num_games_owned': 3035, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1438156685}
review:
Flockers is an action puzzle game in much the same style as Lemmings, created by Team17, makers of Worms, so you know the pedigree is good.

https://youtu.be/YQXgOCYvZFg
For those who don't remember the classic Lemmings, it was a game in which a number of "lemmings" (which looked more like human workers to me) were released and would walk through the landscape, following each other like the archetypal lemmings, blindly walking off cliffs to their death. Your job as the player was to guide the lemmings by giving specific instructions to them, for example to build bridges or dig into the landscape, in order to guide as many of them to safety as possible.

Flockers uses essentially the same concept, but with sheep instead of lemmings. Appropriately so, since sheep also have the habit of following one another. This time around, rather than natural landscapes, you have to help them navigate through extremely dangerous factory complexes, filled with saws, spikes, hammers and other nasty objects, often with gory results as your mindless sheep stroll blindly into them.

Each level is a puzzle. They're large, and get progressively more complicated as you progress through them. You can zoom in and out to get a better view of the puzzle you have to solve. Sheep may wander off in different directions, you may meet more sheep along the way, transporters teleport sheep to different locations and it can sometimes be a bit confusing to understand what's going on the first time you try a new level.

As you go through each level, sheep step on buttons which activate machinery, sometimes in a good way, sometimes in a very bad way, so you have to be very careful what you let them step on. They also encounter crates, which when opened give you new abilities that you can assign to your your sheep. It may take a few attempts to figure out how to get through a level.

While you often need to get only one sheep to safety (in the early levels at least), getting more will score you more points, as will doing it in a faster time. You also get a bonus for using fewer abilities. You can retry levels to get a better score, and you can compare your score to your friends.

The levels are very detailed, perhaps overly so, which can make it tricky to figure out how to solve them. But maybe that's the point, distracting you with unimportant details. Fortunately, although it's an action game, you can pause it at any time, giving you the opportunity to study the puzzle at your leisure. You still have to solve it in real time though, giving commands to your sheep as they move. Pressing the right mouse button gives you a bigger "brush", enabling you to give commands to multiple sheep at the same time.

The graphics are very good, and very gory as sheep get smashed and sawed, spiked and gored, with blood splattering everywhere, which is rather amusing if you find that sort of thing funny. For this reason the game has an age rating. But if you don't like that sort of thing, you can simply turn off the gore in the video options.

I haven't played this game for very long yet, but my first impressions are very good. I'm finding it both challenging and amusing, an enjoyable casual way to pass the time. The price is very reasonable and it's on sale at the moment, so this is a great time to grab it if you're interested.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996886109', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 80, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1414887843}
review:
Despite appearances Flockers does not play much like Lemmings.

Lemmings is primarily a puzzle game, not an action game.  Flockers is primarily an action game, not a puzzle game.  The difference is whether you put the emphasis on difficult reasoning or reacting quickly.

Flockers plays more like some sort of strange platformer than a Lemmings clone.  Unlike Lemmings, there is no way to assign tasks while the game is paused or even slowed down.

Assigning tasks is made more unpleasant by the design of flocker tasks.  In Lemmings assigning a single lemming a task typically affected the behavior of the entire stream of lemmings, or terrain, such as blocking their path and turning them around, or building a staircase until an obstacle was struck.  In Flockers you usually need to give the same task to each flocker at the right time.  Too late is fatal.  Too early may also be fatal, depending on the task and environment.  The only concession the controls make for these demands is to allow you to use a larger or smaller 'brush' to assign tasks, and due to the timing constraints a large brush is not very usable.

To make matters worse, there is no way to predict what the level elements will do.  This reduces solving the level to trial and error, rather than planning.

The constant trial and error gameplay is grueling since you will need to start the entire level over if you  mess up badly enough.

If you want to see what it would be like to play Super Mario Bros. with awkward controls, a stream of Marios, and random cheap deaths, then play this.  If you want to play something like Lemmings, you need to look elsewhere.

Some are making comparisons to Worms as well.  There certainly is no similarity between Worms and Flockers gameplay.  Both Lemmings and Worms had destructable environments.  Flockers does not.  While Worms was violent, and Lemmings had a task that made all the lemmings blow themselves up (used to restart the level), the violence was cartoony.  Flockers is gory.  So Flockers is not very comparable to Worms either.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970329288', 'num_games_owned': 2788, 'num_reviews': 1451, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1410203404}
review:
From the Creators of the award winning 'Lemmings' and 'Worms' Series of games comes another classic in the making from Team 17. I first got to play this awesome and addictive game at 'EGX Rezzed 2014.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vFeH10J_ZV8

If you're a fan of the classic game 'Lemmings' from many moons ago or the recent 'Worms' series of games... then you're in for a treat. Flockers feels like a perfect blend of both styles of game. In Flockers your aim is to guide a flock of sheep to an exit in the safest way possible, along the way you will be met with seemingly impossible obstacles and plenty of gruesome death and you will be laughing all the way! As in 'Worms' you have to collect crate's to aid and help your journey. All in all this makes up for a highly enjoyable and addictive game. Team 17 have not skimped on the gore either this time round and you'll be in stitches and shock at some of the death scenarios. This is already shaping up to be 'Game of the Year' material. The game may still be in 'Early Access' but it doesn't feel that way. It's extremely polished and already has a ton of bonus content with the introducing of 'Steam Workshop' - Highly Recommended!

review:
Fresh take on Lemmings :)   Think Worms Landscapes that are more diabolical, and Lemmings type of Game Play.

I loved playing lemmings when I was a child, this is the more grown-up version of it, with sheep instead of little pixilated men! Can be as gory or non-bloody if you so choose. The new environmental aspects are great, Tellaporters, gravity reversal, mines, sharp bone blades and, Worms driving Death Machines with saw blades and spikes ready to take out your flock without hesitation. Guide your Flock of sheep through the map using ability box's you either start with or pick up along the way, to the trumpet looking exit vacuum. Making sure to do it as quickly as possible without losing too many of your sheep. Sacrifices are usually a necessity, except for rounds where you only have 1 sheep. Knowing that this game is still in Early Access stage, it's one of the best functioning "Alpha's" I've played in quite awhile. 
The only thing I have issue with is moving the camera around. There are times when you move or Pan the camera up, down, left, or right it becomes semi choppy and can be difficult to get the camera where you want it without taking extra time to adjust. I'm pretty sure the DEV's are aware of this issue and are working on it. 
Visually this game is very appealing, Content is still being added, and it even comes with a level editor and, Twitch Streaming features in game.  Other than more levels, and perhaps more Hazards to navigate, you can't really ask for much more.  I wish more early access projects were this "completed" upon steam early access release. 

As it stands, as long as the DEV's don't introduce and major game breaking issues in the future updates, this is a Great Game worth every penny.  Would and will recommend to friends.

review:
The potential for this new generation Lemmings is incredible. The concept is very similar to the loveable green haired creatures but features a greater emphasis on environmental hazards which produce gloriously violent results. The added golden fleece objectives in levels increases the challenge for a perfect score and I can only imagine this going further and further using the editor in the future.

Right now it feels like the overall choice of special effects you can add to your sheep is limited but the heavy environmental interaction makes up for that. 

Established studios using early access might not be totally ok with everyone, but Flockers comes at a reasonable price and is in a relatively polished state for what it currently includes so you can already see Team 17 is taking this new franchise seriously. We've been without a game with as much charm as the original lemmings for a long time and it's great to return to something so familiar with the current generation of polish.

review:
Flockers is a wonderful early access game. The game feels like you are in the sheep factory of a Worms game - training the sheep to become the fluffy little murder machines they are. However, the gameplay is very reminiscent of the Lemmings franchise of the SNES generation. The levels I played were not over the top difficult, but do take planning and a few retries to get 3 stars. It is a great thinking game that kids and adults both could enjoy. If you are sensitive to sheep blood and gore, there is an option to turn off the blood spray.

If you would like to see my first impression video, here is a link: http://youtu.be/KRFZW3a-k0E
